Description: Roughly cubic gaming dice, severely worn and battered surface. The numbers are indicated by holes that may have been filled with black.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Numerous solid six-sided (cubic) dice, predominantly of limestone with drilled pips (but also of faience, ivory, marble, pumice and terracotta) were found at Naukratis. Parallels known from the 7th century BC, but are particularly popular in the Roman period (Cool 2016, 229-231). This had been dated Hellenistic or Roman. It is uncertain whether this is based on the common assumption that such dice are Roman (when they were most common) or whether that is based on the EEF context. Recorded as 'terracotta', but probably limestone. Cool, H. E. M. 2016. The small finds and vessel glass from Insula VI.1 Pompeii: Excavations 1995-2006. Oxford: Archaeopress, Roman Archaeology 17.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (TH.14)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4856 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
